Literature Review: Soft robotics, a rapidly evolving field, leverages the principles of flexibility and compliance to design robots that can adapt to and interact with their environment in ways that traditional rigid-bodied robots cannot. This literature review explores the current state of soft robotics, focusing on actuation, sensing, modeling, control, and machine learning, and discusses the challenges and future directions for the field. Actuation in soft robotics has seen significant advancements, with researchers developing various mechanisms to mimic the complex movements found in nature. For instance, pneumatic actuators have been widely used due to their simplicity and effectiveness in generating motion (Rus and Tolley, 2015). Similarly, shape memory alloys (SMAs) offer the advantage of compactness and the ability to recover their original shape after deformation, making them suitable for applications requiring precise movements (Hines et al., 2017). Sensing is another critical aspect of soft robotics, enabling robots to perceive their environment and adjust their actions accordingly. Advances in soft sensors, such as those based on conductive elastomers, have improved the sensitivity and durability of soft robots, allowing for more accurate detection of forces and deformations (Majidi et al., 2016). Modeling and simulation play a pivotal role in the design and optimization of soft robots. Computational models that accurately predict the behavior of soft materials under various conditions are essential for developing efficient and reliable robots. Finite element analysis (FEA) has been extensively used to simulate the complex interactions between soft robots and their environment (Trivedi et al., 2008). Control strategies for soft robots must account for their inherent nonlinearity and variability. Adaptive control algorithms, which can adjust their parameters in real-time based on feedback, have shown promise in improving the performance of soft robots (Laschi et al., 2016). Machine learning techniques are increasingly being applied to soft robotics to enable intelligent behaviors. Reinforcement learning, in particular, has been used to teach soft robots complex tasks through trial and error (Pfeifer et al., 2007). The application areas of soft robotics are vast, ranging from medical devices and wearable technologies to exploration and rescue missions. Soft robotic grippers, for example, have demonstrated superior performance in handling delicate objects compared to their rigid counterparts (Brown et al., 2010). Despite these advancements, several challenges remain. The development of new materials that can withstand the rigors of real-world applications while maintaining their softness and flexibility is a significant hurdle. Additionally, creating accurate models that can predict the behavior of these materials under a wide range of conditions is still an ongoing challenge. Advanced control algorithms that can handle the complexity and variability of soft robots are also needed. Finally, integrating machine learning techniques to enable autonomous and intelligent behaviors in soft robots is an area that requires further exploration. In conclusion, soft robotics holds great promise for creating robots that can interact with their environment in more natural and effective ways. However, to fully realize this potential, future research must address the challenges related to materials, modeling, control, and machine learning. By tackling these issues, soft robotics can make significant contributions to various fields and improve the quality of life for people around the world.
